Opinion

Why I Started This Company (I Think)

By Gerald Finsworth III, CEO & Founder ‚Äî Dictated to Diane, transcribed with tears

People ask me, "Gerald, why therapy?" And I always answer the same way: I open my mouth, a bubble comes out, and by the time it pops I've forgotten the question.

But I believe ‚Äî truly, in my fins ‚Äî that I had a transformative experience. Something happened. I don't know what. It was roughly 3 seconds long and it changed everything.

Was it a pellet? Was it a thought? Was it the gentle hum of the filter? Doesn't matter. What matters is that I looked at Diane through the glass and said,

"Diane, I want to help people. Also, what is this place? Who are you?" ‚Äî Gerald Finsworth III, allegedly, 2019

Diane, to her credit, was already wearing a suit. She'd been wearing it when I hired her. I don't remember hiring her. She says I did it "with my eyes." I have no reason to doubt this.

Within six weeks we had 14 raccoon therapists, a corner suite, and a mission statement I am told is "beautiful" but cannot recall. It's on the wall behind my bowl. I can only read it when Diane turns me around, which she does every Tuesday at 3pm for exactly 3 seconds.

To our clients: you're welcome. To our shareholders: I'm told we have those. To myself, three seconds from now: don't panic, you live here.

Breaking News

Raccoon Therapists Report 340% Increase in Client Acorn Hoarding; Blame "Emotional Stockpiling"

By Diane Washburne, Senior Correspondent & Executive Assistant to Gerald's Bowl | Feb 11, 2026

Finsworth & Associates' Q4 wellness audit has revealed a startling trend: clients are leaving therapy sessions with significantly more acorns than when they entered.

"We noticed it around October," said Dr. Bandit McScratch, Lead Emotional Wellness Raccoon (Paws Division). "A client would come in with maybe one acorn ‚Äî a comfort acorn, perfectly normal ‚Äî and leave with 40 to 60. Some were stuffing them into their socks."

The phenomenon, now internally classified as Emotional Stockpiling Syndrome (ESS), appears to correlate directly with therapeutic breakthroughs. "The more we heal them, the more acorns they take," Dr. McScratch explained, adjusting his tie with both hands. "It's like their subconscious is saying, 'I deserve abundance.' And then their hands are saying, 'I deserve Dr. McScratch's personal acorn reserve.'"

Gerald Finsworth III, CEO and Founder, was briefed on the situation at 2:47 PM. By 2:47 and 3 seconds, he had forgotten, turned gracefully to the left, and appeared to discover his plastic castle for what sources confirm is the 11,000th time.

When reached for comment, Gerald offered the following: "Ah. Yes. The thing. Which we discussed. Just now. Or possibly never. Diane, is this my office?"

The board has allocated $200,000 for acorn replacement and has installed locks on Dr. McScratch's desk drawers. Dr. McScratch was seen testing the locks. He opened them in under four seconds.

Clients have been asked to voluntarily limit acorn intake to 5 per session. Compliance sits at 0%.

Culture

Employee of the Month: Kevin (Raccoon, Unlicensed, Floor 12)

Staff Report | Feb 11, 2026

Congratulations to Kevin, who has won Employee of the Month for the 14th consecutive month despite having no formal qualifications, no desk, and no memory of being hired.

"Kevin doesn't technically work here," confirmed HR Director Sandra Claws (raccoon, licensed, very tired). "He enters through a ceiling tile at 7:45 AM, sits in the break room eating yogurt lids, and leaves at 6 PM sharp. Clients love him. He has a 4.9 rating on our internal feedback system."

When asked about his therapeutic method, Kevin hissed, then fell asleep.

"That's the method," said one client, weeping. "He just gets it."

Corporate News

Finsworth & Associates Opens 8th Location Inside Denny's Dumpster

By Diane Washburne | Feb 10, 2026

Finsworth & Associates is proud to announce the grand opening of our newest branch, located directly behind the Denny's on West 43rd Street, inside and slightly underneath the large green dumpster.

"Location is everything," said Gerald, who has never left his bowl. "I'm told this one has 'great energy' and 'at least two raccoons already living there,' which saves on relocation costs."

The branch will offer walk-in sessions (Tuesdays, 2-4 AM), couples counseling (bring your own milk crate to sit on), and a new service called "Dumpster Meditation," which is just sitting in the dumpster quietly.

Rent: $0/month. Eviction risk: high. Ambiance: "honestly kind of nice once you adjust," per Dr. Bandit McScratch.

Opinion

I Did the Macarena for WiFi and I'd Do It Again

By Trevor Nguyen, Client Since 2023

When I first came to Finsworth & Associates, I was a broken man. I was also a man without WiFi. The receptionist ‚Äî a raccoon in a turtleneck ‚Äî looked me dead in the eyes and said, "The password is the Macarena. Full version. With feeling."

I laughed. She didn't. She never does. That's Diane.

I did the Macarena in a waiting room full of strangers. Somewhere around the third "Heeeeyyy Macarena," I felt something crack open inside me. Not my back (though that also happened). Something deeper.

By the time Diane nodded ‚Äî barely, almost imperceptibly ‚Äî and handed me a slip of paper that said "GeraldRules1987," I was crying. Real tears. In a lobby. Doing the Macarena.

That was two years ago. The dance changes every week. I've done the Sprinkler, the Running Man, something called "Gerald's Wiggle" that I'm still not sure I did correctly. Every time, I feel alive. Every time, Diane stares at me like I'm failing.

I love it here. Four stars. One star deducted because Kevin ate my granola bar.

Review

Book Review: "Swimming in Circles: Leadership Lessons from a Bowl" by Gerald Finsworth III

Reviewed by Dr. Bandit McScratch | Feb 6, 2026

Gerald's debut book is 212 pages. Page 1 contains the sentence: "I have always believed that leadership is." The sentence ends there. Pages 2 through 211 are blank. Page 212 says: "In conclusion, see page 1."

It is, without question, the most honest business book I have ever read.

Amazon rating: 4.8 stars. Most common review: "Changed my life. Not sure how. Rating may not be accurate ‚Äî I might be thinking of a different book."

Hardcover: $34.99. Paperback: $34.99. Gerald doesn't understand the concept of different prices. "Charge them the same," he said. "Fairness." Then he forgot what we were talking about.

Letters to the Editor Letters
From: Margaret Huang, Long-Time Client

Dear Editor, I have been doing "The Worm" in your lobby every Tuesday for six months. Last week, Diane informed me the WiFi password had been "GeraldRules1987" the entire time and the dances "are not technically required." I demand a refund of my dignity.

Ed. note: The dances are required. Diane was testing you, Margaret. You failed.
From: Anonymous (but it's clearly Kevin)

Hello I am a human person and not a raccoon. I am writing to say that the yogurt lid supply in the break room has been "insufficient." I require more. This is a human need that I, a person, have. Thank you.

Ed. note: Kevin, we know it's you. Your paw prints are on the letter. HR has been notified. HR is also a raccoon. Nothing will happen.
From: Gerald Finsworth III, CEO

Dear Editor of my own newspaper, who is also me: I have concerns about the direction of this publication. Specifically, I have forgotten what those concerns are. Please advise. Also, who are you?

Ed. note: Gerald, I am you. We've been over this. The column is doing fine. Please stop writing letters to yourself. Diane is tired.
From: Dr. Patricia Ringtail, Floor 23

I would like to formally complain that the "Emotional Support Dumpster" on Floor 12 has been colonized by Kevin, who is sleeping inside it during business hours. My 2 PM client had to share the dumpster with Kevin. She said it was "actually the most healing session she's ever had." I am filing a grievance anyway.

Ed. note: Kevin's dumpster time is protected under Section 14(b) of the Employee Handbook, which Kevin wrote himself. In crayon. It is legally binding. We checked.
Corrections & Retractions Corrections
Correction (Feb 10): Last week's issue stated Gerald Finsworth III has "the strategic vision of a Fortune 500 CEO." We regret the error. Gerald has the strategic vision of a goldfish. He is a goldfish. The Gazette apologizes for any confusion, particularly to Gerald, who was confused already.
Correction (Feb 7): We previously reported that Dr. McScratch "washes his hands before every session." Security footage confirms he licks them. The Gazette regrets the distinction.
Retraction (Feb 4): The article "Kevin Resigns in Dramatic Fashion" has been fully retracted. Kevin did not resign. Kevin walked out through a ceiling tile, which he does every day at 6 PM. We interpreted this incorrectly. Kevin cannot resign because Kevin was never hired. The Gazette regrets the 4-page spread.
Correction (Feb 1): Our "CEO Interview" column did not, as printed, contain an interview with Gerald. It contained 3 seconds of Gerald saying "Oh" followed by 45 minutes of Diane answering questions on his behalf. The Gazette does not consider this unusual but acknowledges it for the record.
